div.p: 1. IV. Saturday.

Notwithstanding the heavy showers and thunder of last Evening, the heat of the Sun was so intense and sultry that my visits to my Seminary, Garden and Nursery were short, and without useful observation.— The Sun has arrested the germ of almost all the seedlings of this year, but here and there an Apple tree, pushes up the germ, even as late as now.— So of Pear trees— The maple at the corner of the Seminary, this day opens its eighth pair of leaves, but the night insect has eroded the sixth and seventh pairs—The leaves come out, each pair exactly at right Angles with the last, and the stem is a perfect perpendicular to the ground— This is the natural growth of the maple; but of twenty-five which have come up from the seeds that I brought with me from Washington and Philadelphia, one only has had this rapid growth—five have perished—eight or ten are pining and about ten are thriving— None of them can endure unsheltered the fierce heat of the Sun—and the invisible insect preys upon their tender leaves.— I found several young black caterpillars upon the terminal leaves of the elm sprung from the fragment root in the Summer house cellar— My Son Charles and his wife, with their daughter Louisa Catherine, their infant boy, and their maid Catherine came from Boston, to spend a few days with us. Wilson went to Boston with the Carriage and brought out Mrs Charles and the Children.
2 IV. Sunday.— Sun rose 4:51.

Heard Mr Lunt this morning, from 1. John 5.8. “and there are three that bear witness in earth, the spirit, and the water, and the blood: and these three agree in one.”— This verse immediately follows after that of the three that bear record in Heaven; the Father, the Word, and the Holy Ghost, and these three are one.—the strong hold of the Trinitarians, but the authenticity of which is so vehemently contested, and so feebly maintained— The text itself is in language so highly figurative that its meaning is very obscure— Mr Lunt understands by the Spirit, the miracles performed by Christ—by the water, the purity, and innocence of his life, and by the blood, his death upon the Cross— A very ingenious exposition; but of very questionable accuracy That the single word Spirit should mean the miracles performed by Christ is as hard to believe as that the word water should signify the innocence and purity of his life— Such strained and far fetched constructions lead to the enquiry why the Spirit of God should use dark and mystical language to express plain and simple thoughts— The three witnesses on earth of this text I understand as meaning the Spirit of the Gospel, the baptism of repentance and regeneration, and the blood of Christ— The argument of the chapter is the necessity of believing that Jesus Christ is the Son of God; and the demonstration of this fact is represented to consist in the doctrine of eternal life proclaimed by him— The witnesses to this fact are the immortal Spirit—the purification of repentance, and the Seal of Christ’s blood— And this construction is congenial with the argument of the chapter and of the whole Epistle— Mr Lunt however made a very good discourse by a commentary on the text as he understands it— He made no reference or allusion to the controversy upon the preceding verse which if spurious as it no doubt is; was introduced by some person who had profoundly meditated upon the genuine text of this Epistle, and upon the character of all the writings of the Evangelist John— It was a communion Sermon, and immediately after it the Sacrament was administered by Mr Lunt. I gave Mrs T. B. Adams two Letters which I had received for her and her daughter Elizabeth from New-Orleans— She told me that her daughter Mrs Angier was very ill, with a bilious fever— Afternoon
Mr Lunt preached from Proverbs 22.6. “Train up a child in the way he should go: and when he is old he will not depart from it”— A discourse upon the importance of giving a good education to children; and a particular commendation of Sunday Schools with exhortation to the people of his congregation to give their own Sunday School, an increased support— I took Mary-Louisa to Meeting with me, morning and afternoon— I read the 4th. Sermon of the seventh Volume of Saurin, entitled by him the resources of the Christian.— His text is from the same Epistle, from which Mr Lunt preached this morning. 1. John 4.4. [“]greater is he that is in you, than he that is in the world”— The Sermon is an exceedingly elaborate argument to prove that God is more powerful than the Devil— No trivial task for a Calvinist preacher— And Saurin as usual entangles himself inextricably in the web of his own metaphysics— He concludes that if the Devil does get final possession of the vast majority of mankind, it is owing not to the deficiency of God’s superior power, but to the depravity of man— Elizabeth C. Adams and Mary Harrod were here this afternoon.
3. IV. Monday.

I went into Boston with my Son Charles to attend the adjourned Meeting of the Alumni of Harvard University, at the Hall of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. But there were besides me only two members of the Committee who attended—Mr Robert Charles Winthrop the Secretary, and Dr Charles Lowell— After waiting about a quarter of an hour we adjourned the Meeting to 9. O’Clock of the morning of Commencement day in the Library Hall of the University— As we came out from the Meeting we met Dr. Wainwright who had just returned from Andover, and who was going to attend the Meeting. I left with Dr Bowditch a copy of my Oration upon the Life and character of La Fayette and a copy of the proceedings at the Installation of Mr Lunt, as presents to the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. I called to visit Isaac P. Davis and his Son Thomas, but neither of them was at home— I visited also at Mr James H. Foster’s and at Mr Edward Cruft’s. Saw only the Ladies— Mr and Mrs Cruft were going this afternoon upon an excursion of ten days into Vermont— After making a few emplettes I went to Charles’s Office, and we returned to Quincy to dine—found that the child Fanny had been quite unwell. Mr Josiah Adams junr. who was here upon some carpenter’s work, shewed me the 36th. Annual Report of the home missionary Society, containing what he considered as a libel on the town of Quincy— It is a report to the Society from a man named Cornell, the Minister of the Orthodox Congregational Church recently built here, and who says there are as many as seventy families in the town, who never see a Bible, who never attend at any Church, and within whose doors, no Minister had entered for the last twenty years— And that were, Parents as ignorant is if they were Pagans— Mr Adams told me that his father, the Deacon, had asked him to shew me this pamphlet—that it had produced great excitement, and that there had been talk of calling a Town-meeting about it— Mr Beale was here in the Evening and spoke on the same subject— He said that he and Mr Brigham had been to Mr Cornell to demand upon what evidence he had advanced such grave charges against the Inhabitants of Quincy. Mr Cornell told them that he had no copy of his Letter—that he did not recollect precisely what he had written, and that he had intended no reflection upon the inhabitants of the town, and had expressly said that he did not suppose they differed in this respect from other towns in general. He believed that instead of twenty years, it was only two years that he had written, that certain families had not seen a minister within their houses—and that those who had no Bibles were the roman-catholic workmen at the Quarries— Beale said he did not know but Cornell would be drummed out of the Town— My visit to Boston this morning, curtailed the performance of my daily task.
4. IV. Tuesday

I had promised Alpheus Spear if the weather should be fair and cool to go down to the Mount Wollaston farm, and view the buildings last Saturday afternoon. But the heat of the day and the thunder showers prevented the fulfilment of my intention— Spear, who is anxious to ascertain whether he is to have a new lease of the farm or not came again this morning, and I promised him I would come down this afternoon, as I accordingly did, with my Son— We inspected the lower barn which is in a very ruinous condition, and upon which he claimed repairs to the amount of 200 dollars He wished also to have the house taken down and a smaller one, built upon the same site, and he wanted considerable repairs to the Corn-house— He spoke of selling gravel at a dollar a sloop load at half profits, and he now sends his Son, every morning, at 2. O’Clock rising at one to Boston with milk— Since Huckleberries are ripe, he says his custom has increased, and last Sunday he took with him forty gallons which he sold— All the farms round this neighbourhood are turning to this mode of cultivation, which is simple and convenient, requiring little trouble, and improving the land by the quantity of manure made by the cattle Spear was also very anxious to settle the difference we have had about the Parish-tax, and made me a proposition to compound for it— I took the opportunity to look at my young orchard on the North side of which he has now, a field of Indian Corn. The Apple trees look quite unpromising; but the Oaks, chesnuts and Shag-bark walnuts round three sides of the border are more encouraging to my plantations than any thing else that has befallen me— That they will in twenty years from this time form a grove surrounding, and sheltering the orchard I have the strongest reason to hope, though with a certainty that I shall not witness it myself, and a great uncertainty into whose hands the Estate within that time may fall— We returned home about Sunset, and with Charles and his wife, I went in and spent an hour of a small Evening party at Mr Beale’s—Mr Thomas Greenleaf and his family, Edward Miller with his, Dr Woodward and Elizabeth C. Adams were there— Several rather sudden deaths at Boston within the last week have occasioned apprehensions and rumours that the yellow fever is there— The 8th. and last number of Charles’s Appeal from the new to the old whigs is this day published in the Daily Advocate and in the Sentinel simultaneously— These papers are well written, and form a defence of the Constitution of the United States against one of the most formidable and pernicious assaults that it has ever sustained: and of which the Patronage Bill, which passed the Senate at the last Session of Congress was the first fruit— A politic silence has been observed with regard to these papers, by Daniel Webster and his partizans, and it is yet doubtful, what their effect may be— I visited my plantations, and find the seedlings looking generally fresh since the rains— I trimmed the Apricot tree in the Seminary, and covered the wound with the composition beeswax suet rosin— Staked a willow twig for a Bean pole: and filled Pot 7. with fresh earth in which I buried 3 English Jenneton Pear Cores— The tree is now for the first time in full bearing; and the Pears are sound and good— I had the old Plum trees in the Eastern close washed with Soap-suds and the Moss that had gathered on them scraped off— The 8th. pair of leaves opens on the Seminary corner maple—
5. IV:30— Wednesday. Sun rose 4:55.

My Son Charles went into Boston this morning and brought out his eldest boy John Quincy so that we have now all his family here— Thomas Adams the constable came with a subscription paper, addressed to the Selectmen of the Town, requesting them to call a town-meeting to take such measures as they may think
proper in relation to the charges, against the inhabitants of Quincy of being in regard to religion and the Bible, as ignorant as Pagans— The paper was subscribed by Thomas Greenleaf and Daniel Greenleaf— I declined signing my name to it, and said I was very sorry this poor man had got himself into so much trouble by his indiscretion. That he had written under a religious impulse, and seemed to have forgotten that Charity was a part of the obligations of Christianity— But as he was under the heavy displeasure of the People of the Town, if I should put my name to this application for a town-meeting, it might have the appearance of my taking part against him, which I should not wish to do— Mr E. Price Greenleaf came this afternoon, and budded for me with Summer and Winter sweeting Apples a number of the young stocks growing in my Nursery. Lewis Bass, one of the Selectmen came to enquire upon what terms I would convey to the Town a portion of Land of the Penn’s Hill Orchard, at the bend of the road, sufficient to widen the road— This is an expedient to prevent the renewal of the Petition to the County Commissioners, to open a new road through my Orchard, upon which there was a survey by the County Commissioners last Summer. I told Mr Bass that I should be disposed to do any thing reasonable for the accommodation of the Town; and that as soon as the Season should become cooler, I would go with him and view the ground, and see if we could agree upon the terms on which the Town may have as much of the land as they will want. I received a Letter from Charles J. Cazenove and Co. of Boston, containing a claim for 336:83 upon a draft which they drew upon me in November 1832, but which was never presented to me— The demand is against the Estate of my deceased Son, and is for Sales of flour in 1831. This evening I received a note, from Mr T. B. Wakeman of New-York—written at French’s tavern, enclosing a Letter from George Sullivan, and a Resolution of the American Institute of the City of New-York, requesting me to deliver a public address at the next Anniversary of the Fair of the Institute, and that Mr T. B. Wakeman the Chairman of the Managers and the superintending agent of the Institute communicate this resolve to me in person, with the most respectful solicitations that I would comply with this request— Sullivan’s Letter was very urgent, although written after he had received my answer declining his first invitation, and had made my answer known to the Institute before they passed the Resolution. Mr Wakeman’s note requested me to appoint an hour when I would see him— I answered it that I would receive him this Evening or at any time to-morrow Morning between 6. O’Clock and noon, as would best suit his convenience.
6. IV:15. Thursday

Mr Wakeman came this morning, and I had a conversation with him of about two hours— He was very urgent that I should accept the invitation of the American Institute of New York to deliver the address at their Anniversary Fair, but gave me no reason for it which could outweigh or balance my reasons for declining. I desired him to assure the Society of the grateful sense which I entertained of the honour they had done me by the invitation, and especially by the manner in which they had conveyed it; to add the assurance of my hearty good wishes for the prosperity of the Institute, and for the prosperity of their cause, and further to say, that if in the public Station which I occupy, it may be in my power to render them any service, I shall always eagerly avail myself of it— I stated to him a part of the reasons which require my perseverance in declining to deliver the Address. The general considerations, which dictate the policy of sustaining and cherishing the manufacturing interest were obvious, and had been presented with
eloquence and ability, by the gentlemen, who had delivered the Addresses of the three preceding years—Judge Baldwin, Mr J. P. Kennedy and Edward Everett. To repeat them could neither excite much interest, nor much promote the purposes of the Institute— Should I undertake to deliver the Address, it would be expected of me and I should myself hardly be justified in undertaking it, but with intention of presenting the subject under new and different views; and my own opinion was that the great difficulty under which the manufacturing interest of the Country labours, is a political combination of the South and the West against it.— The Slave-holders of the South, have bought the co-operation of the Western country, by the bribe of the Western Lands; abandoning to the new Western States, their own proportion of the public property, and aiding them in the design of grasping all the Lands into their own hands— Thomas H. Benton was the author of this System, which he brought forward as a substitute for the American System of Mr Clay, and to supplant him as the leading Statesman of the West— Mr Clay, by his Tariff-compromise with Mr Calhoun abandoned his own American System— At the same time he brought forward a plan for distributing among all the States of the Union the proceeds of the Sales of the Public Lands— His bill for that purpose passed both Houses of Congress, but was veto’d by President Jackson, who in his annual Message of December 1832. formally recommended that all the Public Lands should be gratuitously given away to individual adventurers and to the States in which the Lands are situated— Now if at this time, on the eve of a Presidential election, I should, in a public Address to the American Institute disclose this state of things, and comment upon it, as I should feel it my duty to do, it would probably produce great excitement and irritation—would be charged with having a political bearing, and subject me to the imputation of tampering with the election— Mr Wakeman said that this had opened to him a new volume, and explained to him many things which had seemed to him unaccountable— Still he thought my opinions might be presented in such a manner as would not be irritating or offensive, and the Institute would take measures for giving a very extensive circulation to the Address— They had printed 1500 copies of that of judge Baldwin, which had also been printed in Newspapers to the amount of eight or ten thousand— They would circulate still more of an Address from me— I said there were other reasons which admonished me to avoid at this time any occasion of bringing myself before the public eye—particularly on account of the part which I took in the controversy with France, and in that between Ohio and Michigan, both of which I expected would occupy much of the attention of Congress at their next Session— I did not satisfy Mr Wakeman, and although I did not assign to him the strongest of my reasons for persisting to decline, I did not satisfy myself— The strongest of my reasons was a conscious inability to fulfil the expectations of the Institute and of the Public if I should comply.— Those expectations would run high, and would be disappointed— They would turn to disgust, and my discourse instead of having any beneficial influence upon the public mind, would be turned as an instrument of obloquy against myself— So it has been with the exertions I have made against Free-Masonry— So it has been with all my labours for internal improvement
for the support of the manufacturing interest, and for domestic industry, and free labour. So it was for my honest ardour in the dispute with France at the last Session of Congress, and so it will be to the end of my political life— Laudatur et alget. Nothing but an overruling sense of duty can justify me in giving any of my opinions to the public— No volunteering for me— Mr Wakeman took leave, thanking me for the politeness of my reception of him, and with a promise that I would answer Mr Sullivan’s Letter. William Spear came, and I went with Charles and him to the Rail-way quarries. There we met Mr Bryant, who went with us over the ground to the two ledges upon which the Lessees are at work upon my land— Winkley and his party upon one, as yet unsuccessful; Dudley and his company upon the other, where they find excellent stone, but which is likely to be soon exhausted— Bryant said the Railway-company wished to purchase 12 feet wide on one side, and 25 feet wide on the other, along the whole length of their Railway across my lots— We took notice of the bounds of my lots, and returned home to dine— The fatigue of the morning walk, produced a sluggish afternoon and my daily task remained almost wholly neglected.

7. IV:15 Friday.— North-eastern storm— Rain without intermission from morn till night— Confined to the house, with an exception of about five minutes in the afternoon in which I reached the Summer-house cellar and returned. I should have done much— I did nothing but write the Journal of yesterday, and copy the Journal of the close of March and beginning of April 1834— Such weather breeds low Spirits, from which my constant occupation partially preserved me— Yesterday there appeared in Pot N 15 a seedling plant which I did not recognize— It is yet unknown.

8. IV:15. Saturday— The day was fair, and the Sun warm, but the evaporation from the heavy rain of yesterday, made the air cool, and the atmosphere damp. Charles went to Boston, and returned to dinner—Visited my Seminary, Garden, and Nursery— Gathered ripe white Currants in the garden, and sowed a row of them, along the Eastern side of the house; barely covering them with Earth— The first blossom opened on the Easternmost of the two Althaea trees fronting my chamber windows— The corner seminary maple opens its ninth pair of leaves, and is a foot high— My seedling plants have got to be so numerous that my attention is too much scattered among them. The black currants, on the seedling bush first bearing this year, are ripening— The day was devoted to the redemption of Journal arrears, and I came to the account of the 4th. of April 1834, and the suppression by the previous Question, of my intended Speech on the Reasons of Secretary Taney for the removal of the Deposites.— I feel on the revisal of the transactions of that day as I felt at the time, a deep mortification, at the trampling underfoot of the first principles of freedom, in the adoption of the fourth Resolution of the Committee of Ways and Means, and the appointment of the travelling Bank-investigation Committee— It was a measure less pernicious in its effects than in its principle. The Directors of the Bank understood and adhered to their rights—refused submission to their tyrannical inquisition, and sent them back to Washington, as wise and as knowing as when they left it, on their scrutinizing expedition— Thomas the Chairman vented his Spleen, by moving that the President and Directors of the Bank should be brought to the Bar of the House to answer for a contempt, but the motion only served to display in full relief the impotence of his malice, and the happy inability of the House of Representatives to tyrannise, even when they have lost the restraint of self-controul. The issue of this procedure was consolatory to me, as demonstrating the weakness, even of the
House of Representatives in concert with the President of the United States to tyrannize over individual citizens— My opinion however remains unchanged that the House of Representatives dishonoured themselves by a Resolution, which if they had possessed the power of carrying it into execution would have been most arbitrary and oppressive— The grasp at power has been a remarkable characteristic of this Administration, and the President the Senate and the House of Representatives each in turn have manifested the encroaching temper.— Charles brought out from Boston the first volume of the Letters from Horace Walpole, to Sir Horace Mann, of which I read the Preface.
9. IV. Sunday.— Sun rose 4:59.

The Preacher was Harrison Gray Otis Phipps, a Son of the late Dr Phipps, whose sudden death happened in 1832 the day after this young man had taken his bachelor’s degree at Cambridge— This was his first or second performance in the Pulpit, and it was very creditable— The text of his morning Discourse was John 16.32. the latter part of the verse—“Yet I am not alone, because the father is with me.” That of the afternoon was from Romans 6.23. “For the wages of sin is Death: but the gift of God is eternal life, through Jesus Christ our Lord.” There was in his manner earnestness and simplicity— His subjects were well divided, and his thoughts more obvious, and less attenuated with metaphysical refinement than is common among the young Clergymen, from the theological school at Cambridge— There was something of the timidity of a beginner in his performance; enough to bespeak the favour of his auditory, the People of the Parish taking an interest in his success, as a townsman, the Son and Grandson, of Physicians much respected for two generations past— I read also the 5th Sermon of the 7th. Volume of Saurin, upon the necessity of taking heed to our ways— And in the whole collection as I have yet read them, there is not one more full of useful instruction— His text is from Proverbs 4.26. which in the English common Bible reads “Ponder the path of thy feet, and let all thy ways be established.” In Saurin’s French he has it “balance the road of thy feet, and all thy ways shall be well regulated.[”] The words ponder and path give a vividness to this Sentence in the English which it has not in French— There are no corresponding works in the French language. The remarks of Saurin therefore upon the inaptitude of the figurative expressions in this proverb to the French language, do not apply to the English— There is a picturesque beauty in the words ponder the path of thy feet, perfectly congenial to the character of the English Language, and most impressive as a precept of Prudence— This precept Saurin considers, as applied in the text not only to the conduct of men, but to their Sentiments and their judgments— He subsequently however confines the disquisition to the prudence of action—and teaches his hearer to weigh all his purposed actions 1. with the principle whence they spring 2. with the circumstances of the actor 3. With the manner of action 4 With its appropriate limitations 5. with the attainments and capacities of the actor, and 6. with the time of action— Upon each of these heads he gives supposed cases of deliberate action, and directions to suit them— It is obvious that this formal, and methodical meditation cannot be applied to the ordinary and unimportant purposes of daily life; but with regard to all actions leading to consequences operative upon the happiness of the actor, and upon the well-being of others this Sermon furnishes an admirable practical Lecture— The details are equal to the design— I read nothing else. Coll. Josiah Quincy and E. Price Greenleaf were here this Evening.
10. IV. Monday— Sun rose 5.

A fine Summer day, with clear sky, warm Sun, and cool refreshing breeze— I planted from the Eastern end of the Seminary a border of white Currants— Gathered black Currants ripe from the seedling bush— Staked a willow twig, at the gate corner of the Seminary— Purslane, Marsh Mallows, Sword grass are the weeds that now cover my Seminary bed— The English Jenneton Pears, are dropping over ripe from the tree— I have filled Pot 7 and Stand 2. with Cores of this Pear; and deposited Stands 1. 2. in the cellar— Shingle-staked the corner seminary maple 13 inches high, so that the scorching Sun cannot bear upon the germ, which is the fatal stroke to delicate plants— I had a morning visit from Mr Benjamin Gorham, with Thomas F. Foster, a member of the last Congress from Georgia, and General Flournoy. Foster, like all the Georgians, is an ardent politician, somewhat infected with the nullification virus, and stiff as buckram for State-rights, but honest, honourable and talented— He was one of the delegation who lost the Election to the new Congress, by their taint of nullification— Wilde, Gilmer, Gamble met the same failure, the Georgia delegation being elected by general ticket— There are now three vacancies in the delegation; in the Seats of Wayne, appointed a judge of the Supreme Court of the United States, of Schley, who is a candidate for the Office of Governor, and has resigned his seat in Congress, and Terrill who has resigned owing to ill health— Foster said Gilmer had declined being a Candidate—and that Wilde, who is gone to Europe, had left with his brother a discretionary power to declare him a Candidate or not, as he should see fit. It was yet uncertain. Foster said nothing of himself— Mr Gorham invited me to dine with him on Wednesday. In the afternoon I had visits from N. L. White, of Braintree, who is to take his first degree at Cambridge, at the approaching Commencement, and has assigned to him for a part, the character of the late Chief Justice Marshall— He came to enquire of me, if I knew, what had been the judge’s religious opinions— I told him I did not. That I believed he was of the Episcopalian Church, and I presumed judge Story, who had been very intimately acquainted with him, could inform him, what had been his individual religious impressions— Mr White said he was limited to ten or twelve minutes for the delivery of his part— That he had written as much as would take three quarters of an hour to speak, and now was lopping off, till he scarcely knew what he should lop off further. He said he knew himself by his inexperience, incompetent to delineate the character of Judge Marshall, and thought no one could do it, within the compass of the time allotted to him. I said he must measure his ambition, by the reasonable expectations, which would be entertained of his performance, rather than by the copiousness of his subject— He said he had seen and heard it affirmed that the Office of Chief Justice was more important than that of President of the United States, and asked me how that should be— I said it was because the Construction of the Constitution and Laws of the United States was in the last resort given to the Supreme Court; and because the power of constructing the Law, is almost equivalent to the power of enacting it: the Office of Chief Justice of the Supreme Court is held for Life— That of President of the United States only for four, or at most for eight years. The Office of Chief Justice requires a mind of energy sufficient to influence generally the minds of a majority of his associates— To accommodate his judgment to theirs, or theirs to his own. A judgment also capable of abiding the test of time, and of giving satisfaction to the public— It requires a man profoundly learned in the Law of Nations—in the Commercial and Maritime Law—in the Civil Law, in the Common Law of England, and in the general
Statute Laws of the several States of the Union— With all these powers steadily exercised during a period of thirty four years, Chief Justice Marshall has settled many questions of Constitutional Law, certainly more than all the Presidents of the United States together— A person by the name of Philander Ames came to enquire the price of the lot of land belonging to the Estate of Ward Nicholas Boylston, in Charlestown, and whether it belonged to me— I told him it was Mr Boylston’s, and referred him to my Co-Executor Mr Nathaniel Curtis for the price of it— Evening visit from Revd. Peter Whitney. Bath at Noon.
11. III:50. Tuesday.

My Son Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine. Henry Hardwick was here about a quarter of an Acre of Salt-marsh land at the Mount Wollaston farm, which he has been several years wanting to purchase of me— I promised to go and view it, as soon as cool weather should come— I continued clearing the Seminary border Alley of Weeds from the Eastern end, which I began yesterday, and this day proceeded as far as the Apricot tree. Sowed an edge of white Currants from the Eastern fence to the Apricot— In the Nursery I found the leaves at the germ of the chesnut trees, covered with aphides, and the large black Ants travelling about among them— Rubbed off as many of them as I found, with my finger and thumb.— I bathed and swam ten minutes yesterday with Charles, and this day alone at Daniel Greenleaf’s wharf.— The Passage to the Pear and Plum-trees at my Northern garden fence is opened, and the hazel bushes cleared away— They were a harbour for snakes, which infest the garden almost daily— The heat of the day slackened my labour, and left me short of my daily task— I received a Letter from Mr Frye at Washington about my private business; and in great distress and agony at an attempt of a negro-slave of Mrs Thornton, at Washington, to murder her, and her mother Mrs Brodeau. There is a great fermentation upon this subject of Slavery, at this time in all parts of the Union— The emancipation of the Slaves in the British West India Colonies— The Colonization Society here, the current of public opinion running every where stronger and stronger into democracy and popular supremacy, contribute all to shake the fetters of Servitude— The theory of the rights of man has taken deep root in the soil of civil Society— It has allied itself with the feelings of humanity and the precepts of Christian benevolence. It has armed itself with the strength of organized association— It has linked itself with religious doctrines and religious fervour— Anti-Slavery Associations are formed in this Country and in England, and they are already co-operating in concerted agency together— They have raised funds to support and circulate inflammatory Newspapers and pamphlets gratuitously—and they send multitudes of them into the Southern Country, into the midst of the swarms of Slaves. There is an Englishman by the name of Thompson, lately come over from England, who is travelling about the country holding meetings and making eloquent inflammatory harangues, preaching the immediate abolition of Slavery. The general disposition of the people here is averse to these movements and Thompson has several times been routed by popular tumults. But in some places he meets favourable reception, and makes converts— There has been recently an alarm of Slave-insurrection in the State of Mississippi, and several white persons have been hung, by a summary process of what they call Lynch’s Law. That is Mob-Law— Add to all this the approach of the Presidential election, and the question whether the President of the United States shall be a Slave-holder or not. They never fail to touch upon this key in the South, and it has never yet failed of success. Rouse in the heart of the Slave-holder, the terror of his Slave, and it will a motive with him paramount to all others never to vote for any man, not a Slave-holder like himself— There are now
calls in the Atlas the Webster paper, and the Morning-Post, the Jackson-Van-Buren paper at Boston, for a Town-meeting, to put down the abolitionists; but the disease is deeper than can be healed by Town-meeting Resolutions.—
12. IV. Wednesday— Dined at Benjamin Gorham’s Boston.

Mr Beale called this morning and invited us to a party at Squantum to pass the day—my engagement at Boston prevented my joining it— The heat of the weather abridged my visit to my plantations, and to my labour upon them— My Althaea trees are blossoming gradually and the humming birds visit them for their sweets— At two O’Clock I went in the Carriage alone to Boston and dined with Mr Benjamin Gorham— The party consisted of Messrs. Flournoy and Foster of Georgia—Charles Codman Isaac P. Davis, Edward Everett, Abbott Lawrence, Joseph Russell, David Sears, Mr Truman, and myself— Mrs Gorham was the only Lady at Table— Mr Sears has lately returned from France, with his family.— He went with the expectation of procuring for his children advantages of superior education. He returns disappointed and convinced that the Schools whether for boys or girls at Paris are not so good as those of this Country— Davis had a hand-bill from the Atlas Newspaper Office, containing an account of continued riots at Baltimore, on Saturday and Sunday last, in which the Houses of Reverdy Johnson, John Glenn, and John B. Morris were destroyed by the mobility— In those two days, the authorities of the City and of the State appear scarcely to have made an effort to sustain the Laws and the rights of property— The riotous spirit manifested itself also last Night at Charlestown, and Roxbury, by an attempt to celebrate in a tumultuous manner the anniversary of the destruction of the Roman Catholic Nunnery at Charlestown— It is said this was suppressed, but Edward Everett says there were riotous assemblages in the Streets very noisy till late last Night. The Baltimore riot was directed against all the persons implicated in the fraudulent failure of the Bank of Maryland, which happened, nearly 18 Months ago. Mr Abbott Lawrence told me that they were going to have a very great meeting at Boston, to put down the Anti-Slavery abolitionists; but he said there was no diversity of opinion, upon that subject here.— That I think will depend upon the measures to be proposed. If the measures are vapouring Resolutions they will pass unanimously and be inefficient— If the measures are efficient, there will be diversity of opinion— I returned home immediately from Mr Gorham’s, and reached my House shortly before the nine O’Clock bell— Charles and his wife, spent the Evening at Mr Lunt’s. George Whitney has taken his dismission from the Church and Congregation where he was settled— I took with me to Boston the first Volume of the Letters from Horace Walpole to Sir Horace Mann— The Letters are of the winter of 1741 and 1742. and are very interesting, by containing the detailed account of the breaking up of the ministry of Sir Robert Walpole— The Letters from the Minister’s Son, living with him, and himself a member of Parliament, witnessing and reporting from day to day the successive votes marking the decline and fall of a great man from power, afford a melancholy but instructive picture of human nature, in the high political relations of Society— The picture has strong resemblances to others of which I have had more knowledge and experience.
13. IV. Thursday.

Isaac P. Davis told me yesterday, that Dr Charles Lowell, and he were coming out to Quincy, to invite me in the name of the Historical Society, to deliver the Introductory Lecture, to a course of Lectures upon History which it is proposed shall be delivered the ensuing Winter—at the Meetings of the Society— I said I should be happy to
see him and Dr Lowell, whenever it might suit their convenience, but I was apprehensive I should not be able to comply with the invitation of the Society. This I am obliged to do, for consistency’s sake, after so many refusals of similar invitations, but there is nothing which I should more willingly have undertaken than this, and I reproach myself for my own imbecility in rejecting the proposal— But I am now bent upon a work of mere copying, which absorbs all my time; even that of my daily and necessary correspondence, and yet in which my progress is so slow that it will evidently occupy the whole of this Summer, and until the time of my departure for Washington— This was one of the fiery Summer days, during great part of which I was disqualified for work— On rising this morning I found two of my seedling Pots overthrown; one of them Pot 1. with all the Earth in it, thrown out, and the three maple seedlings which had come up in it, rooted out, and withering as they had been all Night— I replaced the earth, and two of the maple seedlings in the Pot, with a little moist fresh earth to keep them straight; and the third maple in another Pot N. 8: filled with fresh earth and watered both the Pots— This accident gave me however the opportunity to see how the first roots of the maple-tree are formed, and how the plant comes out from the wing or fan, in which the seed is enclosed— I planted also in the Hazel patch, just half cleared away, a row of 16 whole jenneton Pears at 15 inches distance from each other—intending to cover the whole of that Patch with seedlings. I further hoed up the weeds in the Seminary alley and have had an alley opened to it from the Easternmost door of the house— Just before 2. I went with Charles and bathed and swam with Charles at D. Greenleaf’s wharf— Mr Beale and his daughter Ann were here this Evening— He asked me to attend the town-meeting to-morrow afternoon at 5. O’Clock. This was my Son Charles’s daughter, Louisa-Catherine’s fourth birth-day.
14. IV. Friday.— Sun rose 5:6—fiery haze at the horizon— Clear above.

There was something remarkable in the appearance of the atmosphere this morning. a fiery vapour in the region of the rising Sun, which portended rain before the close of the day The sky was otherwise clear, and the heat of the Sun so intense that I could not labour, upon my Plantation— In the visit to my Nursery however I found that the borer worm had attacked the two oldest of my seedling Oaks— This worm has almost destroyed the common locust tree in this region of Country— Has committed and is committing terrible ravages among the Apple trees—but this is the first indication I have had of his enmity to the Oaks— He goes directly to the heart of the tree, boring a hole not bigger than the head of a pin from the surface through the bark, and digging round between the wood and the bark to make himself a spacious residence while he penetrates into the wood. I had laid a Stone under the ground, and over the roots of the seedling red Oak, now in its seventh year—with the Inscription “Alteri Seculo” upon it— I am not sure that this worm has not already falsified the prediction and cut off in its infancy my candidate for life in the next century— If I save it now, will it not always be liable to a fatal attack from the same borer worm? and will it not be so with all the works of my hands? when shall I discover a plant for the life of the next century? Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine. I was much disabled all the morning by the heat. About four in the afternoon there came up a shower with light and distant thunder after which there was more freshness in the air— I am still copying, and perseveringly doing nothing— The accounts of the riots in Baltimore continue. In the State of Mississippi mobs are hanging up blacks suspected of insurgency, and whites suspected of abetting them— At Charleston South Carolina Mobs of Slave-holding Gentlemen intercept
the Mails, and take out from them all the inflammatory pamphlets, circulated by the abolitionists, who in their turn, are making every possible exertion to kindle the flame of insurrection among the Slaves— We are in a state of profound Peace, and overpampered with prosperity— Yet the elements of exterminating war seem to be in vehement fermentation, and one can scarcely foresee to what it will lead.
15. IV. Saturday. Sun rose 5:7. Hazy Horizon with clouds.

There was a meeting of the Inhabitants of the Town of Quincy yesterday afternoon, upon the Revd Mr Cornell’s slanderous Report, published in the 36th. Annual report of the Massachusetts Missionary Society, and republished in the Newspaper called the Trumpet and Universalists’ Magazine of the 1st. of this Month— It was a very full meeting notwithstanding the foul weather which prevented me from attending it— This morning a notification by George Nightingale the Town Clerk was brought to me, that a Committee of eleven, John Q. Adams, Josiah Brigham, Thomas Greenleaf, Captain Eliphalet Smith, Noah Curtis, Jedediah Adams, Major Zebediah Hollis, George W. Beale, Ebenezer Bent, Ebenezer Jewett and Frederick Hardwick were chosen, to take into consideration the whole matter of the publication in the Trumpet, and to report to the Town, at the adjournment of the meeting, next Friday, the 21st. instt. such course of proceedings as they shall deem expedient— I desired him to notify the members of the Committee to meet at the town Hall at 6. O’Clock this afternoon. The Committee met accordingly—Nine members present—Captain Smith and Mr Bent absent. After some conversation upon the subject, it was determined that I should prepare a Letter to Mr Cornell, to be signed by all the members of the Committee, apprising him of their appointment, and giving him an opportunity to explain or disclaim, or justify his libellous imputations upon the People of the Town— I engaged to prepare such a Letter, to-morrow morning before Meeting time, to be signed in the course of the day, by all the Committee, and sent to Mr Cornell Monday morning, and requesting his answer before Wednesday Evening 6. O’Clock, to which time the meeting of the Committee was adjourned— Mr and Mrs Barrell were here this afternoon, with Miss Keating. Mr E. Price Greenleaf came; and looked at the cherry-trees which he budded for me, on the 23d. and 25th. of last month— He found the buds had almost all taken, and he brought me some cherries withered for seed-stones. He examined the two seedling Oaks invaded by the borer worms, and into which they have eaten holes at least an inch deep— He thinks however that the trees may yet be saved— He knew that the elm was sometimes demolished by this insect, but knew not that he was also the assassin of the Oak— I found a bright spotted Caterpillar too upon a seedling elm—and swarms of Aphides or green lice upon Chesnut, Willow, and Peach trees— The Jargonelle pears are ripening, and almost all rotten at the core. I finished the weeding of my Eastern Seminary alley, and dug up more stones than weeds. The corner maple is opening its tenth pair of leaves—all the others lag behind—
16. V. Sunday.

President Quincy was here last Evening while I was absent, attending the Committee of the Town— This morning I wrote a Letter to the Revd. William M. Cornell, to be signed by all the members of the Committee— I signed it myself and took it with me to the Meeting-House, where I gave it to Mr Josiah Brigham, the member next named on the Committee, who promised to obtain the signatures of all the other members and to send it to-morrow morning to Mr Cornell— The morning and day was showery, and the atmosphere exceedingly damp,
but cleared up towards Evening— Mr Lunt performed the morning and Mr Whitney the afternoon service— Mr Lunt preached from Romans 13.1. “Let every soul be subject unto the higher powers, For there is no power but of God: the powers that be, are ordained of God.” It was a discourse upon the importance and necessity of Government; and upon the duty of submission to lawful authority. The riotous Spirit which is manifesting itself in every part of this Country has alarmed the friends of order and of Law— The dominion of the mob is taking the place of Governors, Judges and Sheriffs, and all security to the life, liberty and property of the Citizen is shaking to its foundation— Even in this town there has been no small agitation of a question about tarring and feathering of this Revd Mr Cornell— Mr Lunt’s Sermon was a spirited appeal to the sense of Justice, and of order in his auditory. The argument was of course all on his side, and the Sermon was highly seasonable— Mr Whitney’s text was from Proverbs 14.32—“the righteous hath hope in his death”—a consolatory dissertation upon the death of the righteous; in which he avowed his belief that there can be no eternity of punishment consistent with the character of a just and merciful God— Mr Whitney’s voice and his eye-sight are equally failing, and he will probably not much longer be able to perform any of the Offices of public worship. Mr Lunt requested the children of the Congregation, who were present to remain, after the afternoon service and delivered to them a Lecture— I read the 6th Sermon of the 7th. Volume of Saurin, upon chimerical projects— Like the one immediately preceding it is a Treatise of practical morality, and of useful instruction—containing many sagacious observations, and shewing much knowledge of human nature. Preoccupation of mind distracted my attention from it as almost always happens on Sundays, and at my age little of any use is to be learnt by reading— At twenty-one, when I delivered to the Phi Beta Kappa Society an Oration on the same Subject, this Sermon would have been to me a Treasure— Louisa C. Smith and Elizabeth C. Adams dined with us. Mrs Josiah Quincy junr. was here this Evening but I was at Edward Millers with Charles and his wife— Miss Hannah Miller played on the Piano and sung some sacred music. Mr Smith of Cincinnati, a brother of Mrs Charles Miller was there— Mr Beale with his daughters and Dr. Woodward.
17. IV: 45. Monday— Sun rose 5:9. Clear Horizon— Cloudy above.

I rose with a dull heavy head ache, owing as I believe to the extreme dampness of the atmosphere— It passed away before breakfast. I planted rows 2 and 3. in the garden cleared hazle-bush patch, with each twelve whole decayed Pears, jennetons and Jargonelles, and over the second row 120 cherries and stones given me by E. Price Greenleaf— I found on my young seedling elms a pair of caterpillars which I took and placed under a quart glass tumbler Nothing useful can be accomplished in this world without perseverance and consistency of pursuit.— I have wished to ascertain the character of many of these changeable worms by following them through their different metamorphoses; but excepting the Silk worm and one cabbage-worm in 1805 I have never been able to effect it— Last Summer I took in three caterpillars from the willows and they went into Cocoons— But on my return here last May I found they had perished—probably by the frost of winter— The natural History of Insects and of Plants, Entomology and Botany are Sciences which might be improved to great advantage by practical farmers— There scarcely passes a day, but I observe some new phenomenon of vegetation, but I know not how to turn it to use. Among my present observations the most impressive is the difference in the rapidity of vegetation between different seeds of the same plants, exemplified specially in the maple seeds which I brought from Philadelphia and Washington, one of which
has produced a plant now 15 inches high, and opening its tenth pair of leaves, each at right angles with its immediate predecessor, and rising Story above Story, like a Chinese pagoda, while others growing in the same manner have opened their leaves from two to eight pair, and scarce any two of them to the same extent— I have suffered a bed of grass to cover the seedlings in the Eastern seminary, and this with the shingle-sheltering as yet preserves most of them, from the scorching radiance of the Sun— The Season has hitherto been uncommonly favourable to the growth of trees.— My daily task of copying was performed— Mr and Mrs Lunt paid us an evening visit— There was a fire atMrs W. S. Smith has written to my wife to ask for the Papers of the appeal from the new to the Old Whigs, which she says are attributed to me— The Washington Telegraph, in behalf of J. C. Calhoun, is somewhat discomposed, at the appearance of these papers, and has twice published short comments upon them— Dignified silence is Webster’s policy concerning them here.
18. IV:45. Sun rose 5.11

My Son Charles’s birth-day— His age twenty-eight— He went to Boston, and returned to dine. Mary’s child Fanny was very sick in the Night, and Dr Woodward came to see her. Mary Louisa too has a return of the inflammation in her eye, and was unable to read— I received a Letter from Mr Jared Sparks at Cambridge requesting me to return the Manuscripts and books relating to General La Fayette, which he has lent me. Also a Letter from Charles J. Cazenove and Co. which I answered— In the Garden I planted a third row of 12 whole Pears and 120 cherries and cherry-stones—in the cleared hazel-bush patch— Scarcely one of the Willow twigs which I have staked out has failed to put forth leaves— I received from Washington a Richmond Enquirer, containing the Address of the Baltimore Van Buren Convention to the Democratic Republicans of the United-States— There is something extraordinary in the present condition of parties throughout the Union. Slavery and Democracy, especially the Democracy founded as ours is upon the rights of man, would seem to be incompatible with each other— And yet at this time, the Democracy of the Country is supported chiefly, if not entirely by Slavery— There is a small shallow and enthusiastic party, preaching the abolition of Slavery, upon the principles of extreme democracy—but the democratic Spirit, and the popular feeling is every where against them— There have been riots at Washington, not much inferior in atrocity to those at Baltimore— A Slave of Mrs Thornton, made an attempt to murder her and her mother with an axe in the Night— He was prevented from accomplishing his purpose by his own mother; and in revenge for this, mobs of white people at Washington have destroyed sundry Negro houses, school-houses and a church— In the State of Mississippi, they have hanged up several persons for circulating abolition pamphlets— In Charleston South-Carolina the principal men of the State, with the late Governor Hayne at their head, seize upon the Mails, with the co-operation of the Postmaster himself, and purify it, of the abolition pamphlets—and the Postmaster General, Amos Kendall, neither approves nor disapproves of this proceeding— At Washington a man named Crandall has been imprisoned for circulating incendiary pamphlets and in Halifax County, Virginia, a man named David F. Robertson, a Scotch Teacher was in danger of his life, because another man named Robertson was suspected of having dropped in a Steam-boat, the first number of a newspaper, printed at New-York with the title of Human Rights— In Boston, there is a call for a Town-Meeting, signed by more than five hundred names, with H. G. Otis, and P. C. Brooks at their head. This meeting is to be held next Friday, and is to pass Resolutions against the abolitionists, to sooth and conciliate the temper of the Southern Slave-holders. All this is Democracy and the Rights of Man.
19. V. Wednesday. Sun rose 5:12 Edge of Barn

Captain Eliphalet Smith called on me this morning, and said some person had told him that I wished to see him; but this was a mistake: I said perhaps it was someone who knew that I had prepared the Letter to the Revd. Mr Cornell, and was waiting to have it signed by the other members of the Committee of whom Captain Smith is one. He then said he had called here yesterday with Mr Leach the Minister of the Episcopal Church, who wished to be introduced to me; but it was our dinner time; and they had concluded to take another opportunity to visit me. He asked me, if I had received an answer from Mr Cornell, to the Letter from the Committee. I had, early this morning, and read it to him— Mr Smith made also some enquiries concerning his claim against the Government of Chili, for the seizure of his vessel called the Macedonian, by Lord Cochran in 1819 or 20—and asked if the Government of the United States was not itself bound to indemnify the sufferers, having made a Treaty with Chili, while this claim remained unsatisfied. I said I could not answer those Questions— A Bill had passed the Senate at the last Session of Congress, assuming the payment of large claims upon France, on the ground that they had been abandoned, for an equivalent beneficial to the Nation, by Treaty—but it had not passed the House of Representatives— If such an act should receive the sanction of Congress for claims against France, the case of the Macedonian might come within the principle— Perhaps the best course for him and the other claimants now to take would be to write to the Secretary of State, and ascertain what is the condition of the claim as between the Governments; and if it has been abandoned to address a memorial to Congress at their next Session in behalf of the claimants; which if they should so determine, I would readily present, and so far as I should be able, would support— He said he would follow this advice— But must wait the return of Coll. Thomas H. Perkins, now in Europe, and who had lost by that seizure seventy thousand dollars— His own loss had been not less than thirty thousand— He said the robbery had been consummated without the shadow of a judicial process— That Lord Cochran had distributed the dollars among his own ship’s company on the deck of his own ship—and the Chilian Government had converted the vessel to their own use without even the pretence of a trial— At 6 O’Clock this afternoon, Mr Beale called, and I went with him and Mr Thomas Greenleaf to meet the Committee at the Town-Hall— Every member of the Committee was present. Mr Cornell’s answer to the Letter of the Committee was read and discussed— It is very respectful in style and manner, but neither denies the imputations in the report to the Missionary Society, published in their pamphlet, nor adduces any Evidence in support of them— He intimates that all the persons who concurred in the publication are responsible— The Committee determined that the Chairman should write a second Letter to Mr Cornell, calling upon him for the Evidence upon which he made those imputations, and requesting him to answer before to-morrow Evening 6 O’Clock to which time the Committee adjourned their meeting— There was a bright Northern light this Evening, and the change to the coolness of autumnal air was sensibly marked.
20. IV:15. Thursday.

Thomas Adams, brother of Ebenezer and of Deacon Josiah, brought me a petition to the County Commissioners for opening a new road from the Dorchester lower Mills to Jamaica-Plains in Roxbury— He said there were similar Petitions from Inhabitants of Milton, Dorchester and Roxbury— They wished to have signers also from Inhabitants of Quincy, and Mr

Nathaniel Curtis had requested him to apply to me, to head the list of Quincy signers— I declined, because the Petition alledged that the road proposed would shorten the distance between its two ends by 30 per Cent— A fact which I had no right to question, but which I had as little right to alledge—having no personal knowledge of it— That it would shorten the distance I had no doubt; but in what proportion I could not affirm— Nor did I know through what Land the new road might pass, or whether the improvement of convenience to the public would overbalance the injury to individuals from whom the Land must be taken to make it— Mr Adams said something to me, about clearing out the brook behind my houses at the foot of Penn’s hill, upon which I told him I would converse with his brother Josiah— We had morning visits from the two Misses Tufts of Weymouth; afternoon visits from Mr and Mrs Cruft of Boston, with their Son, William S. and Mr Breck of Alabama, and evening visits from Mr and Mrs Daniel Greenleaf and Miss Mary Ann Greenleaf— I wrote to the Revd. Mr Cornell a second Letter in behalf of the Committee of the Town of Quincy, and received his answer— I attended the Meeting of the Committee, at the Town-Hall at 6 O’Clock in the afternoon, and read to them my Letter to Mr Cornell, and his answer which is merely evasive— It was then voted that the Chairman be requested to prepare a report to be made to the town, at their adjourned meeting to-morrow afternoon at five O’Clock— And that the Committee meet at four, to consider and discuss the report— There was some question whether a Corporation could be prosecuted or prosecute for Slander. I proposed that the Letters which have passed between the Committee and Mr Cornell should be reported, with a few brief remarks upon it by the Committee—and that it be recommended to the Town, to pass Resolutions— That the allegations in the Report of Mr Cornell to the Missionary Society, and published in their thirty-sixth annual Report, injurious to the moral and religious character of the Town of Quincy, are false and scandalous— That the Correspondence of the Committee with him, and the proceedings of the Town upon the whole subject be published, in a Newspaper, and inserted in the Town’s Records.— I suggested that perhaps it might be proper to address a Letter to the President of the American Missionary Society, complaining of the publication of this libel upon the inhabitants of Quincy; but the Committee thought this would make more Town-meetings necessary and might lead to angry religious controversy— Just before the Committee adjourned, a Doctor Jacob Richards of Hanover four Corners in the County of Plymouth came in and said there had been a person named Church—he believed William, who had been some time a Revolutionary Pensioner, and then struck off the list because he declined making Oath that he had no property, though in fact he had none— He had afterwards applied for the restoration of his Pension, but died three or four years ago without obtaining it— He had been buried at the expence of the Town of Scituate where he belonged, and his compensation for medical attendance and for necessary medicines furnished him remained unpaid— He had left three daughters all married to mechanics and all poor— The question of Mr Richards was whether the Pension of which this man had been deprived upon a mistaken conclusion that he had property could not now be recovered by his legal representatives? I told him I had heard of many such cases, and of some whose Pensions had been restored during the lifetime of the claimant— But I knew of no instance in which it had been
recovered after his decease— That if it could be done it must be by a special Act of Congress for which the three daughters must petition— In their petition they must state the material facts of the case and authenticate by testimony upon Oath, that of the Pensioners poverty— If they would forward such a Petition to me, I would present it to the House of Representatives at the next Session of Congress, and do all that might be in my power to carry it through; but I could not answer for its success— He said he would write to me on the subject, and asked me to write to him, which I assured him I would— Garden labours, hours of idleness— Evening cold and vivid lightening in the South west with a cloudless sky.

21. IV:30. Friday— Heavy Rain, with Thunder in the Night and till 8 O’Clock this Morning. After writing the journal of yesterday, I was engaged with the intermission only of a half hour for breakfast, till dinner in preparing a report to lay before the Committee of the Town— At four in the afternoon I attended the Committee—G. W. Beale and Noah Curtis, were absent—all the other members present— I read my report, which was approved and signed by all the members of the Committee present— The adjourned Meeting of the Town was held at five O’Clock, and was fully attended— Mr Beale came to the Town meeting and signed the Report— Josiah Brigham was Moderator— He read the proceedings of the former Meeting, stated the appointment of the Committee and said the Town had now met to receive their Report— I then read the Report, and the Correspondence between the Committee and Mr Cornell— The report closed with two Resolutions proposed for the adoption of the Town— The first declaring the Statements injurious to the moral and religious character of the inhabitants of Quincy, in Mr Cornell’s Report to the Massachusetts Missionary Society wholly destitute of truth or reasonable foundation— The second, that this Report, and the Correspondence between the Committee, and the Revd. Mr Cornell be entered upon the Records of the town, and published in the — newspaper.— The blank was filled with the Centinel, the Daily Advertiser and Patriot, and the Trumpet— After the Report was read, and a short pause, the Moderator invited the inhabitants of the Town to express their Sentiments, Daniel Greenleaf moved that the Report of the Committee be accepted, the Resolutions adopted, and the Thanks of the Town given to the Committee for their Services— The question was put separately, upon each of the two Resolutions, and then upon the acceptance of the Report, and all voted unanimously— I moved that all the proceedings of the Town upon the subject should be published with the Report, and the Correspondence, which was adopted. Harvey Field moved that one hundred extra copies of each of the three newspapers containing the proceedings should be printed, so that each householder of the Town should have a copy— Benjamin Bass thought this would occasion unnecessary expence, but he was the only one who voted against it— The Selectmen of the Town, were charged with the publication in the Newspapers— After this Ibrahim Bartlett one of the Schoolmasters of the Town, said that reports had been circulated concerning him, which he wished openly in the face of the Town to contradict—one was that he had said he would take off the ears of Mr Cornell. He never had said so, and whoever asserted that he had was a wretch— The other was that if it had not been for him, there would have been no Town-meeting on this matter— This was an honour to which he was not entitled— He had not signed the Petition to the Selectmen for the Town Meeting— He had even opposed it.— Though he was now glad it had been held. He had thought the publication by the Selectmen would be sufficient—but he had now altered his opinion— Hollis said he hoped the Gentleman would not be alarmed at idle reports of his being inclined to violent measures— Worse things had been said of him, and not
wholly without reason.— The vote of thanks to the Committee for their Services was adopted, and the Meeting dissolved before seven O’Clock— There was a Town meeting also at Boston this Evening to pass Resolutions against the proceedings of the Abolitionists as they are called—the preachers of Slave-emancipation— Evening clear and cold.
22. III:45. Saturday— Saw Sirius— Sun rose 5:16.

The Revd. Samuel Nott junr. Minister of a Congregational Church and Society at Wareham in the County of Plymouth, with his wife paid me a morning visit, of kindness and curiosity, and gave me a small volume of Sermons published by him, and entitled Sermons from the fowls of the Air, and the Lilies of the Field— He told me that he had been some time a Missionary in India, and that he had seen me once in London, at a Meeting of the British and foreign School Society in the year 1816. (13. May) We had some conversation upon the most agitating topic of this time—Slavery and its abolition. He thought that the abolition of Slavery must come—but that it should be gradual; beginning by attaching the slave to the soil, like the Serfs in the North of Europe— I said Mr Rufus King had expressed a similar opinion in a Speech on the Missouri question, in the Senate of the U.S. but I believed the Slave-holders would never consent to it— My own opinion is that the Planters of the South will separate from the Union in terror of the emancipation of their Slaves, and that then the Slaves will emancipate themselves by a servile War. This consummation may be yet remote, and must be preceded by the sacrifice of the Public Lands to the Western States, effected by the co-operation of the South, to purchase that of the West, in perpetuating the Servitude of their Negroes.— This Coalition accomplished the election of Andrew Jackson as President of the United States, and is now in full vigour to secure the election of his successor. This is the under current, with the tide of Democracy at the Surface— Mr French the Postmaster came and spoke to me of a Letter from West-Point charged with Postage, and which I had sent back to him unopened. I told him I would receive no Letter charged with Postage— My Son Charles went to Boston, and took with him his daughter Louisa-Catherine— He kept her there, but returned himself before dinner— My morning visit to my Garden, Nursery and Seminary was long, but useless— The vegetation of almost all my seedling plants has ceased for the Season, but the Peach trees continue to grow, and two or three of them in the Eastern Seminary are three feet high— Here and there a seedling Apple still shoots its plumelet upwards, and two or three of the Chesnut Oaks, have put forth a third shoot this Season— I covered up in Stand 4. Pear Cores, Cherry stones and a few black Currents, and placed it in the cellar.— And I planted in the ring patch fronting my Study window, five cherries—and at the Eastern end of the Seminary one Apricot Stone.— I looked into Rees’s Cyclopaedia, Volume 6. for some explanation, and account of the dog-days, but it is very confused and unsatisfactory. He attributes the name of Canicular days to the antient Egyptians—says they were adopted by the Greeks and quotes Hesiod and Homer, Virgil and Horace. That the common computation of the dog-days, is of twenty-days before and twenty days after the Heliacal rising of Sirius which he fixes about the 11th. of August— The dog-days thus would be from the 21st. of July to the 1st. of September—but he says that a very proper alteration has of late been made in the Almanacs (English) making dog-days begin the 3d. of July and finish the 11th. of August— That is the time during which Sirius is in conjunction with the Sun and is undoubtedly the hottest succession of forty days in the year— Our Almanacs make dog-days begin the 25th. of July and end the 5th. of September, which is about 20 days before and 20 days after the heliacal rising of the dog-star, but certainly not the hottest portion of the year. Some of them are frosty dog-days.
I found also in Schubert’s popular Astronomy Vol. 1. p. 269. my authority for making of the Star Sirius a class by itself— Schubert says it of Sirius and Canopus; but Canopus is a Star never seen in Europe, nor in the Northern part of America.
23. IV:15. Sunday.

Heard Mr Greenwood of Boston, in the morning from Psalm 139.1. “O Lord, thou hast searched me, and known me.” The discourse was the common argument for the existence of a God, inferred from the evidence of design in all the works of Creation, but it was stated in a light rather different from the usual one— He said that in contemplating the proof of design, of the adaptation of means to ends, in the movements of the Heavenly bodies, in the organization and structure of animals and of vegetables upon earth, in the perpetual demonstration of predisposition which is exhibited to our senses— It becomes not only incredible, but inconceivable how all this universal harmony in the operations of Nature should exist, and yet that there should be no being in the Universe to whom it is known— This knowledge is not in matter itself— Mind only can predispose—and where predisposition is made manifest to our own intelligence, we cannot resist the conclusion that it was produced by intelligence distinct from matter— There is then a mind to which the system of the Universe in all its immensity and all its innumerable varieties must be known—and that being is God— But this discovery can be practically useful to men only, by the application of it to their own existence—by the consciousness that the intelligence with which they themselves are endowed, is of the same nature as that which understands and knows the system of the Universe— It is distinct and separate from the matter of which their bodies are composed, and subject to none of its Laws—as the creating, knowing Spirit cannot die, the portion of it bestowed upon man must be immortal—and for the enjoyment and exercise of it man must be accountable to the source whence it was received— The novelty and ingenuity of this statement of the argument struck me very forcibly,—and the deduction of human responsibility to the creator, from the proof of his existence in the necessity of intelligence to understand what intelligence has made was itself the work of a powerful mind— There was an apparent connection between this Sermon and that of the afternoon, from Psalm 4.6. “There be many that say, Who will shew us any good? Lord, lift thou up the light of thy countenance upon us.” He said this enquiry was as common now as it was in the days of the Psalmist— Many still say who will shew us any good?— The Psalmist does not answer directly the question; but calls upon God to lift upon him the light of his Countenance— This is the answer full and complete— Under the light of the divine Countenance all is good. Poverty—disease—death—the heaviest calamities that can befall the condition of man—all are good— This closing part of the Discourse was eloquent and pathetic—and altogether the two Sermons left a pleasing and grateful impression upon the mind, of piety to God, and of gratitude and contentment under own condition of life— Mr Greenwood’s delivery is cold, inanimate and drowsy.— My wife took Fanny with her to Meeting, but she was unwell there and her grandmother came out with her and brought her home— Louisa was unwell too and did not go— Mr Whitney was in the Pulpit— I read the 7th. Sermon of the 7th. Volume of Saurin upon the variety of opinions— A discourse of a peculiar character, strongly indicating however the skeptical turn of the author’s mind— The text is from Matthew 16.–13–17. the enquiry by Jesus of his disciples, who men said he was—and who they, the disciples said he was? with Peter’s answer, that he was the Christ—and the reply of Jesus that this was a special revelation to
Peter, from God— There are some very severe reflections upon Peter’s apostasy after having received this Revelation— Some bitter Satire upon the preacher’s auditory— He discusses the motives of Jesus in asking this question; who men said he was? He turns to his hearers, and asks what answers they would receive, if they should ask the question what men said of them; and what would be their motives for asking it— Their motives might be jealousy, vanity, idle curiosity; and one would be answered that men said he was a thief, another an adulterer, another a false witness against his neighbour— He says too that when the disciples answered Jesus that some said he was John the Baptist, some Elias some Jeremias, or one of the prophets, they suppressed the most odious things that were said of him, because they would not repeat blasphemies— Finally he says that he has no taste for religious metaphysical subtleties— That whoever tells him, that nothing is certain, he sees clearer light in the opposite opinion— That when he affirms that he has a material body and an intelligent Soul, and that his will is free, he finds himself sustained by a light impossible to be found in the opposite propositions— A Sophist, says he, [“]may imagine objections that I could not solve; but he could not find reasons to counterbalance those which determined me: he may embarrass, but cannot convince me”— These are the concessions of a doubting mind—and they explain why Saurin’s argumentative objections to his own doctrines are always stronger than the answers to them— I performed this day my daily task of writing, and in the Evening read some pages in the Autobiography of Sir Egerton Bridges.
24. IV:10. Monday

Charles went to Boston this morning, and returned before dinner. He brought out with him his daughter Louisa-Catherine. I spent the forenoon from Breakfast time in the Garden, Nursery, and Seminary— I planted a fourth row of whole Pears, (Catherine) just gathered from the tree, in the cleared hazel bush patch, and four whole Pears, in the Nursery, before the western wall, and near the eldest seedling Oak—The old St. Michael and St. Germain Pear trees in the Garden bear very full, but the fruit is all blighted. The corner seminary maple, shews the germ of its eleventh pair of leaves, and the corner chesnut Oak near it, puts forth a third shoot— What an infinite variety of modes has Nature to produce the same results!— E. Price Greenleaf came this afternoon, and examined the buds in the young cherry-trees which he inserted on the 23d. and 25th of last Month— Almost all of them have taken, and the stems of some of the trees have swollen so that the yarn bandage made a furrow round them— One bud of an Apple stock, inserted last Summer, from Solomon Thayer’s Mount Wollaston Apple, is just now opening to put forth a leaf.— In the innumerable disappointments, which befall me since this plantation fancy came over me, these occasional incidents of success, not only more than balance them with pleasure, but afford a continually repeated enjoyment, delusive indeed like all the pleasures of the imagination, but which occupy and pleasingly agitate the mind— When I lose a plant, especially one which I have cherished, and enjoyed in hope the painful sensation is ridiculously acute, but is momentary and soon forgotten; but the plant that comes up; that grows from day to day the first Season and from year to year afterwards is a continual feast—and as it grows, and gives growing hope of proving hereafter useful by producing fruit, it affords enjoyment not unworthy of a rational being— I cannot bring myself to take much interest in flowers, because they pass off, and perish leaving nothing behind—but the trees now seemingly as evanescent as the petal of a rose, and which yet one hundred years hence will bear delicious fruit, or afford a shelter and a shade to after ages of men;
these yield me delight— Serit arbores quae alteri saeculo prosint—never was I believe sentiment deeper seated in human heart than in mine— My walnut tree now in its thirtieth year, now grows every year in beauty and usefulness, and there is a growth in its descendents about the garden and Nursery all planted by my hand, and which in the next century may be pointed out as such— My Seminary Maple of which three months since I picked up the seed at Philadelphia affords me daily amusement, and has taught me the process of Nature in the production and growth of that kind of tree.— This Apple bud, which has been 13 Months in the stock, and now first shewing a sign of life is another pleasure, though the hope of its continuance is but slender— For the constant failures of my plantations teach the vanity of human life, as their success is among its best enjoyments. Mr Brigham called on me this morning, with the copies of the proceedings of the Town, and of the Report of the Committee, which the Selectman Lewis Bass is to take with him to-morrow to Boston that they may be printed in the Centinel of Wednesday Morning— Brigham left them with me.

25. V. Tuesday— I was up last evening till near midnight, and rose this morning at 5 with a sore throat, hoarseness and pressure upon the lungs— I sent Wilson to Mr Brigham’s shop, with the manuscripts of the Town meeting proceedings revised for publication— Planted a row of red Currants along the border of the Seminary bed from the Apricot to the Elm— I had planted a row of white currants from the Eastern fence to the Apricot, and intend to plant a row of black currents from the Elm to the corner gate— To form together a border along the whole bed, and if life is spared me to ascertain if each of the three sorts will propagate its kind.— Also a row of Apple-seeds and cherry-stones, along the Eastern end of the house— My Catherine Pears are now fully ripe, and most of them are sound, and not worm eaten— I received a Letter of notification from President Quincy, to attend as one of the judges of the Boylston prize Declamations the day after Commencement, and to dine with him that day— I had before received a Card for Commencement day, and to dine in the Hall, but do not propose to attend on either of those days.
