I had also a notification from Mr Robert Charles Winthrop, the Secretary to the Committee of the Alumni Meeting— But as that has been a total failure as I was placed upon the Committee without being consulted; as I have attended three of its meetings, at which there was no prospect of its leading to any useful result, and as I disapprove altogether the special object proposed by the meeting, on the last Commencement day, at which I was not present, and as at the last convocation of the Committee only one member, with the Secretary attended except myself, I have concluded to give myself no further trouble about it— The original purpose of raising from the contributions of the Sons of Harvard, a sum of one hundred thousand dollars for the improvement of the Institution was good; but the direction given it by Mr Hosea Hildreth with the co-operation of Judge Story, of diminishing the expenses of education indiscriminately for the wealthy and the indigent made it in my judgment a worse than useless project— Mr Hildreth is since dead— He never met with the Committee, and Judge Story when he found that his plan would not be adopted, fled the course, and did not attend the Committee a second time— I went this Evening to Mrs T. B. Adams’s with a Letter from her Son the Midshipman Joseph H.—dated U.S. Ship Delaware 74. off Malta 30. June. Mrs Adams has been the last month chiefly at Medford nursing her daughter Mrs Angier who has had a long bilious fever— Elizabeth is now with her— Louisa C. Smith is with Mrs Adams—and a Miss Harrod. Edward Miller came in hoarser than myself. There was a great fire this Evening at Charlestown.
26. IV. Wednesday.— Commencement day—

Light and copious showers, succeeding each other with little intermission the whole day through— My sore throat and hoarseness scarcely perceptible in the day time became troublesome again this Evening, perhaps because disregarding the rain, I spent too much of the morning in visiting my plantations— I finished the border row of white, red and black Currants in the Eastern Seminary, and sowed over the row of whole Catherine Pears in the Garden, cleared Hazel bush patch, a part row of Apple-seeds from the Tree at the North end of the Nursery. Planted a willow stake at the North-west end of the Nursery, and at the South west end, trimmed an Elm growing from an old stump; but which from little more than a twig, has grown in seven years to be a considerable tree— I continue doggedly my copying from loose sheet journals, into my last volume, and with which I have laborious occupation for one month more, with even good health— Charles went into Boston, and returned to dine— My wife has been these two days much more unwell, than myself, and was this day confined to her chamber—great part of it to her bed— The proceedings of the Inhabitants of Quincy, in Town-meeting, upon the slanderous Report of the Revd. W. M. Cornell, with the Report of the Committee and their correspondence with Mr Cornell are published in the Centinel of this day— I attempted to resume the reading of one of the Dissertations on the Congress of Nations to abolish War, but could make no progress with it— They are uncompromisingly dull.
27. IV. Thursday—

A restless and almost sleepless night. I awoke before two O’Clock with a burning throat, great hoarseness, dull pain across the eye-brows and some fever— A free perspiration soon came on and gave me some relief— It continued till the entry Clock struck four and I arose— Repairing to my Library chamber I found myself weak and faint but upon lying down on the bed about half an hour I recovered so as to be able to write: and so the day was employed. I visited my garden, nursery and seminary, but abstained from all labour in them and observed nothing to notice in the growth of my plants— Intermitted hearing my grand-children read— I consulted Dr Woodward who was here, and advised a teaspoonful of calcined magnesia to be mixed with the Seidlitz powder to-morrow Morning— Thus I worried through the day and in the Evening, with Charles and his wife called first at Mr Beale’s, but he was not at home; and then at Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s where we found him and his daughter Anne— We came home as the town Bell was ringing nine— I took a warm foot bath, and cup of sage tea and went to bed— My wife is recovering from her indisposition, but kept her chamber all this day— I was copying the account of my excursion to Harper’s Ferry, in May of last year, and it brought to my mind more pleasing recollections and associations during those three days, than I can find in the four months retravelling through that long Session of Congress— This revision might indeed be useful to me, were I thirty years younger than I am;—but how can what I learn now be useful to any one? Seized by the throat as I have been the last two Nights, the only thought which ought to absorb all the faculties of my Soul is my own approaching dissolution, and the dispositions which I can make of my worldly affairs, for the future well-being of my posterity— All this I know and feel, with deep conviction, and yet pass on from day to day, as if I neither knew nor felt it at-all— October next will be three years since I made with great care and consideration a Will— The state of my affairs has since then considerably changed; that of my family still more— I ought to make now another Will; but in the Spirit of procrastination, postpone it, for the chance of another year of Life, reserving it for one of the labours of the next Summer.
28. V:15. Friday

I slept so sound in the Night that I did not hear the ringing of the Bells for a fire on the borders of Braintree, by which a new unfinished house that Mr Nathan Pratt was building was burnt down— It was also five O’Clock, and close upon Sunrise when I rose, with the symptoms of my sore throat much abated, but with those of the catarrhal cough still very troublesome, and the dull feverish head-ache— The whole day was showery and sultry, and I was much confined to the house, but not duly industrious— Mr Richards of Braintree came with a subscription paper, to remunerate as it was expressed Mr Pratt for his loss last Night by the fire— Alpheus Spear came, and had a long conversation with me, about the renewal of his Lease, but we could not agree upon the terms and he left me, declaring his determination to look out elsewhere— Mr E. Price Greenleaf came with a present of Greengage, and other small plums, to Mrs Adams, who still keeps her chamber. He spent the Evening with us.— One of the buds from Solomon Thayer’s Norton Quincy Apple-tree inserted by E. Price Greenleaf in a Stock in my nursery on the 13th. of August last year, is now putting out a shoot and opening a leaf— The only one that has succeeded.

29. IV:15. Saturday.— Charles went to Boston and returned to dine— Mary with her two children, and Charles’s wife went also to Boston, and returned to dine late—4. O’Clock P.M. Elizabeth C. Adams came back with them and went immediately home.— Mary took her children to Boston to have their ears bored, which operation was performed upon Mary-Louisa Her eyes still suffer much with inflammation— There came a man with a Subscription paper for the relief of Mr George Spear shipwrecked last Wednesday in his vessel, by striking upon a rock, going to Bangor— And another man, who said his name was John Adams and was born at Springfield, who enquired if we had any Clocks or watches to repair, and said that he had a curiosity to see me— The symptoms of my catarrhal cough are subsiding— In my Garden I had a trellis set up, for the grape-vine from the seed sown last Autumn by my Granddaughter Mary-Louisa, though with little prospect that it will survive even the ensuïng Winter— I find by consulting Michaux, that the two kinds of Maple of which I brought the seeds from Washington and from Philadelphia, are the red flowering Maple, and the White Maple—these are the only two kinds of which he gives the fructification as vernal— His book describes seven other kinds among which is the Sugar maple, with autumnal fructification; the seed ripening in October— The growth of my white maples is rapid, and promising That of the red very slow and discouraging.— I sent to Boston this morning a small trunk, with the manuscripts and books which Mr Sparks had lent me relating to La Fayette— I had written last Evening to Mr Sparks to give him notice of this—
30. V:15. Sunday.

Heard Mr Lunt this morning from Matthew 9.12. “But when Jesus heard that, he said unto them, They that be whole need not a physician, but they that are sick[”]— Mr Lunt as he seems usually to do, related the occasion, upon which these words were spoken with a brief comment intermingled with the narrative— Then recurred to the leading idea that Christianity is a medicinal regimen for disease, he adduced the prominent infirmities in the moral and intellectual nature of man, as examples of the diseases which it is the object of the Christian dispensation to heal—of these he said little till he came to the mention of enthusiasm, at which all the remainder of the discourse was pointed. He defined enthusiasm to be an extravagant excitement of the mind, accompanied with a delusion of the imagination,—and he painted with energy the evils to which it gives rise— He was particularly severe upon religious enthusiasm, and upon the absurdities that flow from the hallucination of a belief that there is a special communication of influences of the divine Spirit—he spoke of it as of a species of insanity. The
afternoon Sermon was from Proverbs 22.1. “A good name is rather to be chosen than great riches”—and it was a pleasing and useful exposition of the advantages of a good name— There is no doubt that to this time, and in this age as in that of Solomon a good name, is preferable to great riches, but the acquirement of it seems equally beyond the controul of the greater part of mankind— It is not more in the power of a man to obtain the possession of a good name, than that of a great Estate— Riches may be acquired by industry and frugality, with a moderate share of good fortune, but a good name excites envy, malice, and hatred, an all their active energies for its destruction— This is emphatically the destiny of a good name whenever eminently acquired; and so dependent is it upon the chances of Fortune, and the caprices, the prejudices and the Passions of others, that no virtue can be sure of attaining, and no exertion can enjoy the privilege of retaining it— A good name therefore like great riches, is a Lottery ticket— Happy he who wins the prize—but no man must flatter himself that shall gain by deserving it— Mary and Charles’s wife with their daughters attended the morning service— I read the 8th. Sermon of the 7th. Volume of Saurin, upon the uniformity of the conduct of God— A discourse altogether speculative and not practical; as indeed must necessarily be all discourses upon the attributes of the Deity. The drift of the preacher was to shew, that in the infinite variety of the operations of God, there is undeviating uniformity of object— That Order is Heaven’s first Law results from the perfections of the divine Nature, and with this clue we can account for all seeming inconsistencies in the economy of nature, and in the successive improvements in the Covenant between God and man— Mr Degrand came out from Boston, and took tea, and spent the Evening with us.
31. IV:30 Monday

list.item: Rochester with a Letter from Frederick Whittlesey at Boston

div.p:
Barnard Sargent who was here on the 11th. of July, came again this morning and brought a deed executed by him, and drawn by Asaph Churchill, of his right to the Soldiers bounty Land in the State of Ohio, about which he had spoken to me before— He wished me to send this deed to Washington, to be delivered to Governor Cass, and to receive from him the 50 dollars in payment— But Churchill had drawn the Deed so carelessly that he had spelled his name in three or four different ways in the body of the Deed, and never once, as he himself signed it— I told him this might raise an objection to the reception of the deed by the grantee— He took back the deed and said he would bring it again to-morrow Evening. Another man, named Charles Adams Cummings, came with a claim somewhat similar. He had a brother named Stephen Cummings junr who in the Summer of 1819. died at Sea, of the yellow fever four days out on a passage from New-York to Mobile— He had served in the army in the last War with Great Britain, and received a pension— Just before sailing from New-York, he wrote a Letter to his father saying, that he had a Land-warrant for 320 Acres, in the State of Illinois, and situated within one Mile of Vandalia, the Seat of Government of that State. What has become of the Land warrant they do not know— But the father of the deceased who is his heir, wishes to recover the Land, and this young man who is now living here with Mr Fiske came to ask my advice what to do— He shewed me a copy of the Letter from his brother, written at New-York a few days before his death, and stating that he had the Land-warrant, for 320 Acres— I advised that his father should write a Letter to the Commissioner of the General Land-Office, stating the facts, and requesting a copy of the Land-warrant,
from the Record in the Office— And when the copy shall be obtained, that enquiry should be made what is the present condition of the Land— I offered to forward the Letter to the Commissioner of the General Land-Office—to receive his answer, and if there should be occasion, to make enquiries concerning the Land, of any of the members of Congress from the State of Illinois I thought the greatest danger was that the Land had been sold for the payment of taxes— He said he would get his father to write to the Commissioner of the General Land-Office, and would bring me the Letter— Mr Lewis Bass the Selectman came this afternoon and again asked me to go and view the ground on Penn’s Hill where they wish me to give Land to widen the road— He said they had staked it out— I promised if it should be cool weather to go and meet him there Wednesday afternoon at four O’Clock— I had an afternoon visit from Mr William Lee of Boston, whose wife died about this time last year, and who lives now as a desoeuvré—and at the dusk of the Evening there came as visitors, Messrs. Rochester, Schermerhorn, Haight, Jewett and Pratt, from Rochester, New York: they brought a Letter of Introduction from Frederick Whittlesey who came with them from Rochester, but is unwell, at the Tremont House in Boston— My writing was cut short by these visitors, and my garden labours were abridged—

Day. I still rise between four and five in the Morning, but as the Sun now rises atI have a full hour of morning twilight which requires the light of my lamp for reading or writing— We breakfast about 8. after which I spend at least three hours in my Garden, Nursery and Seminary—weeding, detecting worms and caterpillars, brushing away cobwebs and planting cherry-stones, apple and pearseeds, and gazing at vacancy— I return to my chamber and write till between two and three when we dine, and after an hour of idleness, I write again till the dusk of Evening; which now comes earlier from day to day. The time slips away in conversation with my family, till ten which is my hour for retirement— I have suffered the weeds and grass to spread over my seminary, so that I cannot count my seedling plants in it, as at the close of the two preceding months— It has however saved the lives of most of them from the scorching Sun. I gathered this day seven full ripe early Ann peaches from one of my seedling trees.
